name: Atom Zombie Smasher
description: The zombie apocalypse is upon us and it's up to you to evacuate everyone before they fall prey to the undead. Conduct massive rescue operations with a helping hand from snipers, artillery crews, orbital bombardments, and more.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP/Vista/7 Processor: 1GHz Memory: 512MB Hard Disk Space: 60MB Video Card: 60MB OpenGL-compatible Optional: Gamepad or Joystick required for multiplayer

I just reinstalled this game and I have to say that I forgot how fun it is. AZS is a strange amalgam of tower defense, zombie horde killing, and a puzzle game. You manage a variety of mercenaries to control a zombie outbreak while rescuing civilians. When things take a turn for the worse you can call in the Catbird Cannon and the trusty Llama Bombs to eradicate entire city blocks and the zeds they contain. AZS never takes itself too seriously and that's probably my favorite thing about it. The soundtrack is amazing, the game is super cheap, and I can't reccommend it enough.

In short: What you won't found here is pretty graphics or voice acting or deep story. Also it does have steep learning curve and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ AI for the civilians that will run into the zombies in an attempt to run from them(WTF). For some reason they run to their death faster than they run to their rescue. On the plus side: it's a sorta-roguelike, real time tactics (with planning phase just before the onslaught begins) funny game with minimalistic graphics about surviving a zombie infestation. Also HIGHLY MODDABLE which is great.  The intersting mechanics: each side has it own milestones to achieve and the first side to reach the goal points wins. Some encounters are more defensive (rescue and not really returning fire) and some are all about destroying the other side. It depends on the resources at hand (mostly available mercs), the encounter modifier, the current situation and of course on the player itself.  Can't say I'd recommend it to everyone but for 3$ (when on sale) is at least worth checking out. If the trailer for the game doesn't scare you and you like moddable roguelikes (= high replayability) it is well worth the 10$.

Its kind of like a tower defense game but without towers and instead of preventing enemies from getting to one point you're trying to prevent a hoard of zombies from converting city survivors into fellow zombies. You use a helicopter to round up nearby survivors and evacate them while you're mercs hold off the zombies. Not all mercs are purely combative though. You have infantry, snipers, and artillery but there are other units like the zombie bait or barricades that don't kill the zombies but rather slow them down. They can also level up and you can select permenant upgrades for them. This game has a uniquie art style and music and although the gameplay graphics are simplistic (purple boxes = zombies, yellow boxes = survivors) it's somewhat charming.  Overall, its a fun strategy game with a zombie twist which is rare.

A very light RTS style game where you strategically place randomly selected units such as Snipers or Barricades to protect your helicopters landing zone. You have a minimum amount of people to rescue on each level and anyone touched by a zombie instantly becomes one themselves. This can prove disastrous when you have the majority of the people on the map waiting at your landing zone and a lone zombie comes in and converts the entire lot of them. This really makes you plan your unit placement very carefully, which is really the core gameplay. After the match starts there’s usually not all that much to do but watch, save for a few actions such as changing your landing zone location or redirecting your snipers cover area.  I was surprised by how much I enjoyed this game, this is not even a genre I would consider my favorite. There are quite a few game modes to choose from but I found the game to be very easy if you opt to be able to pick which units you use every match. I found being forced to come up with new strategies when the units were selected randomly to really be the main challenge and fun of the game.  -Playtime- The game is a lot of fun for a fairly short amount of time. While you can play as many campaigns as you want with varying game modes, the core gameplay doesn’t really change much and the game will probably wear out its welcome after about 10-15 hours.  -Achievements- Nothing that different from what you would do during normal gameplay, most are just accumulative achievements. Luring massive hordes with Bait into waiting Dynamite for its kill achievement was fun though. 100% becomes a grind for the 500 Gold Medals, once you have Artillery built up a matches can take less than a minute each but it's still a grind.  Recommended on sale.

Mind - it's been about four months since I last played this game. That noted, I highly recommend it, at least when it's on sale.  The game is fun, unique and has an interesting (if not limited) plot. Unfortunately, it can get repetitive and I feel that it could use more to 'do', as after a certain point you're just doing the same thing over and over with little to up the difficulty or change game play. It can also walk a fine line between 'way too short and easy' and 'tiringly long and boring', depending on what features you choose to enable or disable from the start. I've also begun to run into a few glitches (crashes), which make playing it challenging.  Still, it's fun and unique, and that makes it a good deal better than most of the content you find.  Over all: 7/10.

Atom Zombie Smasher is a my favorite Blendo Games title. It's a brilliant casual realtime strategy game that's tense, strategic, flexible, and most of all, a lot of fun. I've heard a few people describe it as 'tower defense', but that's really pigeon-holing it and doing a disservice to a new player's expectations. It's true that a large portion of the strategy is in controlling the flow of the enemy, but it's not nearly as deterministic and simple as that implies. Also there are no towers. The feel of the game is much more about thinking on your feet, and dealing with disasters as they're unfolding in real (or slowed down) time.  You can play any way you want by modifying the campaign settings, letting you restart levels at no cost for that perfectionist victory, or turning on permadeath and a variety of difficulty mods for more intense and less forgiving sessions.  The entire game takes place in the same universe as Brendon Chung's other tiles, including Gravity Bone, 30 Flights of Loving, and Flotilla. Chung's unique humor and sensibilities come through in the form of a large number of vignettes and background articles describing the characters in and around events of the game, and the whole experience is topped off with an amazing instrumental surf rock soundtrack by The Volcanics.

I see a lot of reviews for this game that rave about its difficulty and ingenuity, but at the end of the day it's dots killing dots. The default settings makes the game pretty hard, which is fine for a few rounds, but after a while you get tired of the same dots killing dots over and over, so you decide to try some mods. Then you see how easy it is to make a mod yourself. Then suddenly you got all the achievements.  7/10

In brief: The closest genre I can compare this to is a tower defense game but it doesn't really fit there. This is a constantly moving, mechanic changing strategy game that has an interesting story underlying it.   At length: The first mechanic of this game relie on an war-map / risk type of strategy. You must determine which hotspots to evacuate to either stymie the invading horde or attempt to clear the area and regain that territory for points. This is measured with a victory bar that adds point from this macro strategy and the micro strategy below.   The larger part of the game is an evacuation / extermination of a city to determine the fate of the territory. There is an open ended goal system which I feel is very refreshing to tower defense games in that you can succeed the mission by rescuing the minimum amount of people, the maximum amount or killing zombies. There are modifiers built in to change your gaming experience on multiple play-throughs.   On a flavor/aesthetic front this game oozes character. The surfin' style of music and occasional comic interludes gives a light hearted feel despite the crushing decisions you make in this game. And the game is fully aware of it.   My only gripes about the game are #1: The learning curve was rather off. While the freedom of mods in game helped even it out to my style I found casual to easy and normal unwinnable without any mods. Although I may be missing another level of strategy. #2: I'm not sure if there is a gallery for all the articles/comics/jokes the game gives but they are disjointed and while they stand alone, I never felt I got all of them.  All in all this is a nice little game to get into on desktop but this game really shines on a non-gaming laptop.
